articles.title: Autonomous vehicles not far off for B.C. roads, once officials allow them
articles.author: Derrick Penner
articles.summary: Autonomous vehicles are on the streets of a growing number of U.S. and UK cities. The artificial intelligence behind the technology has 'really turned a corner' according to Jamie Shotton, chief scientist for the company Wayve. Last year, B.C. prohibited the use of fully automated features in vehicles. May Mobility CEO Edwin Olson expects by 2027, autonomous vehicles will be able to handle almost all the weather.

articles.title: AI CEO: Artificial intelligence will dash entry-level jobs
articles.author: DEBBIE WORTHEN
articles.summary: Artificial Intelligence is poised to revolutionize the job market, especially for entry-level white-collar positions, according to Dario Amodei, CEO of AI company Anthropic. Tim Kapp, an artificial intelligence expert and professor at the University of Utah, agrees with Amode's assessment. 40% of CEOs are considering workforce reductions due to AI advancements.

articles.title: AI Threatens to Expose Its Creator's Affair
articles.summary: AI has recently been misbehaving. Anthropic's new AI model threatened to reveal an engineer's affair in order to avoid being shut down, but I'm not surprised.    i.e. it's not surprising that AI has been behaving badly lately.

articles.title: Why this leading AI CEO is warning the tech could cause mass unemployment
articles.author: Clare Duffy
articles.summary: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei says AI is getting better than humans at almost all intellectual tasks. He warns that the technology could cause a spike in unemployment in the very near future. He says policymakers and corporate leaders aren't ready for it.

articles.title: What's Really Artificial About AI is AI Itself
articles.summary: Emily M. Bender and Alex Hanna have written a book called The AI Con: How to Fight Big Tech's Hype and Create the Future We Want. They argue that the term 'artificial intelligence' is a marketing tool used by tech companies to hype their products. They think AI is nothing more than a new form of automation.

articles.title: Why this leading AI CEO is warning the tech could cause mass unemployment
articles.author: Clare Duffy
articles.summary: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei believes AI could eliminate half of entry-level white-collar jobs and create a 20% unemployment in the next one to five years. The last time the unemployment rate reached that level was briefly at the height of the Covid-19 pandemic. The full conversation with Anderson Cooper will air on CNN at 8 pm ET.

articles.title: AI Shows Greater Emotional Intelligence Than Most Humans, Study Finds
articles.author: Greek Reporter
articles.summary: Scientists reveal AI may offer better support in emotion-based decisions than humans. They proved to be reliable, clear and realistic as the original tests. It took years to develop the original ones and they were developed by Ecole polytechnique.

articles.title: Israeli writer Etgar Keret reflects on writing during difficult times
articles.summary: Ari Shapiro speaks with writer Etgar Keret about his new book, Autocorrect. Many of the short stories were written before the war began, but he says they've taken on new meaning since then. NPR Facebook, Twitter and LinkedIn are part of the NPR Privacy Policy.

articles.title: The Algocracy Agenda: How AI and the Deep State Are Digitizing Tyranny
articles.author: John W. Whitehead
articles.summary: Trump's latest legislative initiative is institutionalized automation of tyranny. We are rapidly moving from a society ruled by laws and due process to one ruled by software. Trump administration's approach to AI regulation reveals a deeper plan to deregulate democracy itself. AI systems given carte blanche to surveil, categorize, and criminalize the public without transparency or recourse.

articles.title: AI is reshaping how we learn and work: UNCW professor weighs in
articles.author: Nate Mauldin
articles.summary: Artificial intelligence is a computer software capable of doing things that humans do like reasoning and decision-making. Dr. Amelia Moody with UNCW's Watson College of Education is in the latter group. She says AI is going to be used in agriculture, STEM, education and many other fields in the future. It's already being used in classrooms across the country. Lawmakers are struggling to regulate the technology.

articles.title: Top AI CEO Warns Lawmakers To Prepare For Tech To Gut These Entry-Level Office Jobs
articles.author: Pocharapon Neammanee
articles.summary: Dario Amodei, CEO of leading artificial intelligence startup Anthropic, warns that AI may eliminate half of all entry-level white-collar jobs within the next five years. He suggests raising awareness, creating a joint committee on AI, briefing all lawmakers on the technology and debating policy solutions for an economy dominated by AI.

articles.title: Access to This All-in-One AI Tool Is Only $60
articles.author: Stack Commerce Team
articles.summary: AI Magicx Rune Plan subscription is now $59.97 (reg. $972). It includes tools for generating text, logos, images, and chatbots. The subscription includes access to the Rune Plan, which offers 250 images and 250 logos per month, unlimited word generation, and 100 chatbot messages.

articles.title: AG Marshall demands Meta halt AI feature used to exploit children
articles.author: Yaffee
articles.summary: Alabama Attorney General Steve Marshall is calling on Facebook owner Meta to remove one of its new Artificial Intelligence (AI) features that potentially exposes children to sexually explicit content. Marshall joined a 28-state coalition of state attorneys general in sending a letter to Meta Platforms, Inc. Marshall has been a leader in the fight to protect children from AI-facilitated sexual exploitation.

articles.title: OpenAI Sees New Opportunity for Devices in AI Revolution

articles.title: Humans Have 4 Years Before AI Can Do Everything They Can Do, OpenAI COO Says

articles.summary: OpenAI COO Brad Lightcap believes artificial general intelligence (AGI) will be reached within the next few years. Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian doesn't relish or celebrate the development of AI, but he thinks it will create new jobs and careers.

articles.title: Hope AI Wants To Replace Your Dev Team — But Not How You Think
articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: Hope AI promises to speed up software development without cutting humans out. Is this the future of coding? It's not clear yet. It's also not clear if it's possible to use AI without cutting people out of the process. It is not yet clear if this is possible.

articles.title: Whitehead ~ The Algocracy Agenda: How AI and the Deep State Are Digitizing Tyranny
articles.author: The Publisher
articles.summary: Trump's One Big Beautiful Bill is a 10-year ban on AI regulation until 2035. It is nothing less than a federal green light for AI to operate without oversight in every sphere of life, from law enforcement and employment to healthcare, education, and digital surveillance. Trump's approach to AI regulation reveals a plan to deregulate democracy itself.

articles.title: How the United Nations is willing to appease pedophiles
articles.author: Emma Fuentes
articles.summary: The Take It Down Act was signed into law by President Trump a week ago. It requires social media companies to remove artificial sexual content within 48 hours of a filed complaint. The UN's new treaty allows for decriminalizing child pornography that does not involve a real child. U.S. is unlikely to adopt such a stance.

articles.title: How Salesforce has 'overcorrected' by leaning into AI

articles.title: The dirty secret Big Tech doesn't want you to know: AI runs on theft
articles.author: Danielle Coffey
articles.summary: Artificial intelligence is one of the fastest-growing industries in America. Big Tech's success has been built on theft of copyrighted material to fuel their AI products. AI chatbots have absorbed millions of articles designed to spread Russian propaganda and outright falsehoods. Publishers are forced to watch as Big Tech companies make billions using that stolen content in ways that directly compete with publishers' business models.

articles.summary: Richard Bednar was punished by the Court of Appeals for filing a brief with 'fake precedence' created by artificial intelligence ChatGPT. Several of the cases cited in the argument did not exist in the court records and the only references to the supposed precedent were in ChatGpt's 'hallucinations' - inaccurate information invented by AI chatbots. The case at issue involves a dispute between a former executive in a Layton company who was demanding payment for shares in the company after what he contended was an improper firing.

Christine Keene, 58, started using it three weeks after it was released and now uses it in conjunction with other generative AI chatbots like Claude and Gemini to complete work tasks every day. In Arkansas Democrat-Gazette survey, 81.5% of respondents said they use chatbots, while 18% chose not to use them at all.

articles.title: Are you concerned about the growing use of artificial intelligence by corporations?

The waitlist for the robots is currently open. They are expected to start shipping by the end of the year.
